author: Special Correspondent
text:
A group of international volunteers is building new homes for the marginalised sections in Chettikuppam.

As part of the ‘BUILD’ initiative of the NGO, Habitat for Humanity, 14 volunteers from the U.S., two volunteers from Canada and 13 student volunteers from Habitat Campus Chapter, Japan, are engaged in the construction of homes.

Women from local self-help groups are also involved in the work.

The ‘BUILD’ initiative is being undertaken across the country by Habitat for Humanity, involving volunteers from corporates, schools and colleges. Beneficiaries too contribute their sweat equity and build homes and toilets, said Rajan Samuel, Managing Director, Habitat for Humanity India (HFH India). The activity launched on February 29 will go on till March 14. It is part of the NGO’s Women’s Week Celebrations, 2016 coinciding with the International Women’s Day.

“Yearning a house with proper sanitation facilities is a deep desire of all women across the country. By providing access to decent housing and sanitation facilities, we intend to improve health and provide security for the whole family which is a major step in helping improve their lives,” Mr. Samuel said.

The 2015 rains had destroyed several homes in Chettikuppam at Puducherry. Since 2005, HFH India has built more than 1,000 homes here benefitting over 4,000 individuals. HFH India is building 11 more homes in this village.
title: Marginalised sections of society to get new homes
